STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
January 10, 2024
Courtney Atkins
ISABELLA COUNTY DHHS
1919 PARKLAND ST,
MOUNT PLEASANT, MI, 48858-6017
RE: License#: CP370201201
Dear Courtney Atkins:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on January 9, 2024. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616) 204-
6992.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Melinda Gubbins, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
701 S. Elmwood, Ste. 11
Traverse City, MI 49684
(231) 342-3721
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP370201201
Licensee Group Organization: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Designee: Demetrius LuJuan Starling
Chief Administrator: Courtney Atkins
Name of Agency: ISABELLA COUNTY DHHS
Agency Address: 1919 PARKLAND ST
MOUNT PLEASANT, MI 48858-6017
Agency Telephone #: 9897728400
Original Issuance Date: 01/01/1992
Service Types: Place children for adoption, Certify foster
homes for license, Supervise Independent
Living, Place children in foster home,
Evaluate Applicants for adoption

II. METHODS OF INSPECTION

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12311 Foster parent/agency agreement
(2) The foster parent/agency agreement must
contain all of the following provisions:
(d) That the foster family has been informed of, and
a grees to follow, agency policies and procedures.
Two of three foster home files reviewed did not have documentation the foster
parents were provided orientation as required.
CPA Rule 400.12311 Foster parent/agency agreement
(3) An agency shall document review of the foster
parent/agency agreement with the foster family at
least annually and, when needed, develop a new
a greement.
Two of three foster home files reviewed did not have documentation foster
parents were provided the foster parent agency agreement as required.
CPA Rule 400.12312 Foster parent training
(4) At least 1 adult member of the household shall
have training in and maintain a current certification
in first aid and cardiopulmonary resuscitation from
the American Heart Association or the American
Red Cross or other institution approved by the
department.
One of three foster home files reviewed did not have current certification in first
aid/CPR as required.

CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation
(3) An agency shall complete a special evaluation
within 45 calendar days after receipt of the
information. If additional time is required, then the
agency shall inform the foster parent, in writing, of
the basis for the extension and the expected length
of the extension. The total time for the completion
of the investigation may not exceed 90 calendar
days without written approval from the chief
administrator of his or her designee.
One of two special investigations reviewed did not contain documentation the
foster parent was notified timely of the need for an extension and did not contain
written approval from the chief administrator the investigation exceeded 90
calendar days.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all
of the following information before the placement
or replacement of a child:
(a) Child’s name.
(b) Child’s date of birth.
(c) Available known information about the child’s
health.
(d) Any known history of abuse or neglect of the
child.
(e) All known emotional and psychological
(f) All known behaviors of the child.
(g) Circumstances necessitating placment or
replacement of the child.
(h) Any other known information to enable the
foster parent to provide a stable, safe, and healthy
environment for the foster child and the foster
family, including information about siblings who do
not reside in the foster home as provided in federal
law.
(i) Name of the assigned social service worker.
(j) Authorization to provide routine and emergency
m edical care.
Five of six foster care case files reviewed did not contain documentation that all
information required within subsection a-j of this rule was provided to the
caregivers within the timeframes outlined within the rule.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
2/28/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 3/16/2023

CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans
for each child and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial
removal and at least once every 90 calendar days
t hereafter.
Two of eight foster care case files reviewed (2 of 22 service plans) did not have
the Updated Service Plan completed timely.
CPA Rule 400.12502 Program statement
(2) An agency shall give a copy of the program
statement to a youth before placement in
i ndependent living.
One of one independent living files reviewed did not have documentation the
youth was provided a copy of the program statement prior to entering
independent living.
CPA Rule 400.12503 Policy and procedures
(3) An agency shall provide a youth in independent
living with a copy of the agency’s policies and
p rocedures required by this rule.
One of one independent living files reviewed did not contain documentation the
youth was provided a copy of the agency's policies and procedures as required.
CPA Rule 400.12510 Independent living contract
(2) The agreement must be signed and dated by the
youth and the social service worker. The
agreement must be reviewed with the youth at
least once every 90 calendar days and a copy
provided to the youth.
One of one independent living files reviewed did not contain documentation the
independent living contract was updated and provided to the youth every 90 days
as required.
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meeting
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as
outlined in the following tables:
Case Plan Development/Reassessment
Initial Case Plan (ISP) – within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date.

Updated Case Plan (USP) – within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) – within 30
calendar days before the case plan due date.
Placement Preservation/Disruption
At least three business days prior to a planned change
of placement or no later than three business days after
an unplanned placement change.
Planned and unplanned placement changes include
reunification, placement in a residential setting, step-
down from a residential or hospital setting, return from
AWOLP, or request for change in foster home/relative
placements.
Three of six foster care case files reviewed did not have FTM’s completed as
required.
FOM 722-06B FTM Documentation
The DHS 1105, FTM Report, must be completed for
every FTM.
The caseworker must enter the FTM information in
MISACWIS using the FTM hyperlink within seven
buisness days of the FTM.
Two of six foster care case files reviewed contained FTM’s without the DHS 1105
or the DHS 1105 was not uploaded within seven business days.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
2/28/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 3/16/2023
FOM 722-08D Treatment Plans
When completed, obtain all signatures as appropriate,
including those of parent(s)/guardian(s), foster care
worker, supervisor, foster parent, caregiver, any youth
aged 14 and older and in the case of placement

agency foster care cases, the local DHS office
designee.
Two of six foster care case files reviewed (5 of 22 service plans) did not contain
all of the required signatures on the parent agency treatment plan (PATP).
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
2/28/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 3/16/2023
FOM 801-03 Medical passports
For children entering foster care, the initial medical
passport must be provided within two weeks of the
child’s placement date to the following:
• Foster care provider.
• Young adult voluntary foster care (YAVFC)
youth/young adult re-entering foster care.
The actual date the medical passport is provided must
be documented in the electronic case management
record.
All medical information within the medical passport
must be current and updated at least quarterly to
reflect the child's current and complete health
information.
An updated medical passport is provided to:
• Participating legal parents if the child is a
temporary court ward.
Quarterly, while in out-of-home placement.
At reunification. Subsequent medical
passports are not required after reunification.
Non-offending parent, subsequent medical
passports are not required after reunification.
• The child’s foster care provider at or prior to each
placement.
Note: Non-offending parent with custody of the
child is not considered a foster parent placement.

• All medical and mental health professionals to
whom the child is newly referred to and accepted
for treatment or services prior to or at the first
scheduled appointment while the foster care case
is open, regardless of placement. Subsequent
medical passports are not required.
• Older youth/young adults:
Upon initial independent living placement
(youth aged 16 and over).
Upon exiting the foster care system (young
adults aged 18 and older).
YAVFC youth/young adult:
Within two weeks of re-entry into
voluntary foster care.
Upon exiting voluntary foster care.
Five of six foster care case files reviewed did not have medical passports and
required signatures.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
2/28/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 3/16/2023
1/25/2022 RENEWAL, CAP approved 2/3/2022
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Annotate on signature line of PATP if document is mailed, emailed, client
refused, etc.
• Documentation regarding placement should be uploaded in the placement
section on MISACWIS.
• DHS 901 semiannual needs to follow the same timeline the DHS 1105 and
should be uploaded within 7 days.
• Check all applicable boxes for FTM’s if being held for more than one purpose.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• The facility did not request or require consultation.

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows. The
agency submitted an acceptable corrective action plan in response to the interim
inspection completed on 2/28/2023 with a corrective action plan approved on
3/16/2023. During the review the agency had six violations. Four violations were
noted as repeat violations in the current inspection. During this period under
review the agency noted that overall compliance was impacted, in part, by staff
turnover and inexperienced staff.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The assessment reported the agency's difficulty in meeting requirements during
this review period. The agency has experienced staff turnover. In addition to staff
turnover, the agency has experienced a high number of placement crises over the
past review period. This has added to the job stress and somewhat impacted the
ability to comply with licensing rules.
The Chief Administrator (CA) stated the previous year CAP yielded some
improvements. The agency focused on training and enhanced supervisory
oversight. The CA noted the agency showed improvement in parent child visits as
well as worker parent visits. A review of missed metrics is reviewed during case
conferences and the Quality Assurance Analyst has assisted in supporting staff.
The CA expressed confidence that several areas will improve over the next review
period.
Financial Overview
NA
Staff Interviews
Interviews were conducted with two staff via telephone. Staff reported feeling
supported by the agency. Supervisors and coworkers assist as needed. Staff did
not report any concerns or areas of need.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency maintains sufficient office space, equipment and supplies to ensure
delivery of foster care and licensing services. Records are stored securely.

VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
The DCWL Agency Analyst identified two safety concerns as follows:
Safety Alert #1: Unlicensed relative did not respond to multiple attempts by the
Agency Analyst to schedule a home visit.
Resolution: Agency contacted the unlicensed relative and was able to conduct a
home visit the same day. Agency was able to verify wellbeing of youth placed in the
home as well as ensure licensing rules were being followed. Agency provided
pictures to verify safe sleep was being followed and the home had functional carbon
monoxide detector as well as smoke alarms.
Safety Alert #2: Youth reported to Agency Analyst one of the unlicensed relatives in
the home slaps her butt, is having an affair, and allows an individual with a CSC
conviction in the home and around the youth, including picking her up from school.
Resolution: Allegations unlicensed relative touched youth's butt was called into
Centralized Intake. An investigation was completed with no findings. Allegations
unlicensed relative allows an individual with a CSC conviction around the youth were
also called into Centralized Intake. An investigation was completed with no findings.
The individual in question does not have CPS history or a CSC as reported and
there was no evidence, he gave the youth a ride home from school.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.

_________1/9/2024________________
Melinda Gubbins Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
_ _______________January 10, 2024_____________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
